Big Mike,

Thanks for the info. I don't know that the system I have in mind=
 will
require any tweaks to JUnit. I think all of my code can run along sid=
e of
it, so I won't need to fork JUnit at all. I will know more in a couple=
 of
days.

I'm very much a JUnit rookie, so I won't presume I can improve i=
t. :]

If I get some code working I will post a link to it so other JUnit u=
sers can
evaluate and make suggestions on improving it.

Landon

idered, but there is a

th all that said, I think David Saff response covers your initial

> Big Mike

it] Gathering and displaying supplemental information about
> > test failur=
es.
> >
> >
> > I have a question about the options for gathering and displ=
aying
> > supplemental information about test failures. Please allow me to
=
> > illustrate my question with a simple example.
> >
> > I've got a class =
called Coordinate that represents a point in a 3D
> > coordinate system. I'=
ve overloaded the toString method of this class
> > to write out the X, Y, =
and Z values of the coordinate in a simple
> > String. Now I want to test m=
y toString method using JUnit.
> >
> > If the Coordinate.toString test meth=
od fails (because the string was
> > not constructed in the correct format)=
 I would like to provide the
> > programmer running the test with a copy of=
 the incorrect string, since
> > it provides valuable clues about what is b=
roken with the method under
> > test. I typically do this by placing System=
.err.println statements in
> > my test method. However, I realize that usin=
g System.err.println isn't
> > the most portable or elegant way to provide =
this information to the
> > programmer executing the test.
> >
> > What I r=
eally want is a GUI that allows the programmer to select a
> > failed test =
from a list of failed tests, and then to view supplemental
> > test data I =
provide him/her.
> >
> > I was thinking I could do this by completing the f=
ollowing tasks:
> >
> > - Implementing the RunListener interface in JUnit.
=
> > - Create an extension of Exception that could contain a HashMap of
> > =
simple parameters and that would be passed to the constructor of a
> > Fail=
ure object from within a test.
> > - Creating Failure objects in my tests t=
hat contain the supplemental
> > failrure data.
> > - Passing these failure=
 objects to my RunListener implementaiton.
> > - Creating a FailureProcesso=
r class that displays a GUI with the
> > information in my RunListener impl=
emenation to show the programmer
> > executing my tests the supplemental fa=
ilure data as described above.
> > (FailureProcessor would be an interface =
so that you could do different
> > things with the supplemental failure dat=
a, not just show it in a GUI.)
> >
> > Before I begin this work, I wanted t=
o ask if there was a better way to
> > do this. I know I could use a loggin=
g framework from within my test
> > method, but I really want to work withi=
n the JUnut framework, not
> > outside of it. I also want a nice little GUI=
, not a log file.
> >
> > How are other programmers handling instances when=
 they want to display
> > supplemental data on failed tests? Does my approa=
ch sound reasonable?
> >
> > The Sunburned Surveyor
